images.altText: A shoreline view of Stanley, Falkland Islands, with a cruise ship in the background. Stanley is the islands' main shopping area (population about 2,100).
images.caption: A shoreline view of Stanley, Falkland Islands, with a cruise ship in the background. Stanley is the islands' main shopping area (population about 2,100).

nodes.data: slightly smaller than Connecticut

nodes.name: Background
nodes.data: Although first sighted by an English navigator in 1592, the first landing (English) did not occur until almost a century later in 1690, and the first settlement (French) was not established until 1764. The colony was turned over to Spain two years later, and the islands have since been the subject of a territorial dispute, first between Britain and Spain, then between Britain and Argentina. The UK asserted its claim to the islands by establishing a naval garrison there in 1833. Argentina invaded the islands in 1982. The British responded with an expeditionary force and after fierce fighting forced an Argentine surrender on 14 June 1982. With hostilities ended and Argentine forces withdrawn, UK administration resumed. In response to renewed calls from Argentina for Britain to relinquish control of the islands, a referendum was held in 2013 that resulted in 99.8% of the population voting to remain a part of the UK.

nodes.name: Environmental issues
nodes.data: overfishing by unlicensed vessels; grazing threatens important habitats; soil erosion from fires

nodes.name: Climate
nodes.data: cold marine; strong westerly winds, cloudy, humid; rain occurs on more than half of days in year; average annual rainfall is 60 cm in Stanley; occasional snow all year, except in January and February, but typically does not accumulate

nodes.name: Executive branch
nodes.data:
chief of state: King CHARLES III (since 8 September 2022); represented by Governor Alison BLAKE (since 23 July 2022)

head of government: Chief Executive Andy KEELING (since April 2021)

cabinet: Executive Council elected by the Legislative Council

election/appointment process: the monarchy is hereditary; monarch appoints the governor, who appoints the chief executive

nodes.name: Flag
nodes.data: description: blue with the UK flag in the upper-left quadrant and the Falkland Island coat of arms centered on the right half of the flag; the coat of arms has a white ram above the ship "Desire" (whose crew discovered the islands), with a scroll at the bottom bearing the motto DESIRE THE RIGHT

nodes.name: Independence
nodes.data: none (overseas territory of the UK; also claimed by Argentina)

nodes.name: Industries
nodes.data: fish and wool processing; tourism

nodes.name: Judicial branch
nodes.data:
highest court(s): Court of Appeal (consists of the court president, the chief justice as an ex officio non-resident member, and 2 justices of appeal); Supreme Court (consists of the chief justice)

judge selection and term of office: chief justice, court of appeal president, and justices appointed by the governor; tenure specified in each justice's instrument of appointment

subordinate courts: Magistrate's Court (senior magistrate presides over civil and criminal divisions); Court of Summary Jurisdiction

note: appeals beyond the Court of Appeal are referred to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council (in London)

nodes.data: fish, squid, wildlife, calcified seaweed, sphagnum moss

nodes.name: Geography - note
nodes.data: deeply indented coast provides good natural harbors; short growing season

nodes.name: Economic overview
nodes.data: British South American territorial economy; longstanding fishing industry; surging tourism prior to COVID-19 and Brexit; recent offshore hydrocarbon discoveries threaten ecotourism industries; no central bank and must have British approval on currency shifts

nodes.name: Political parties
nodes.data: none; all independents

nodes.name: Suffrage
nodes.data: 18 years of age; universal

nodes.name: Terrain
nodes.data: rocky, hilly, mountainous with some boggy, undulating plains

nodes.name: Government type
nodes.data: parliamentary democracy (Legislative Assembly); self-governing overseas territory of the UK

nodes.name: Military - note
nodes.data: defense is the responsibility of the UK, which maintains a military presence on the islands

nodes.name: Country name
nodes.data:
conventional long form: none

conventional short form: Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas)

etymology: the archipelago takes its name from the Falkland Sound, the strait separating the two main islands; the channel was named after the Fifth Viscount of FALKLAND, who sponsored an expedition to the islands in 1690; the Spanish name for the archipelago derives from the French "Iles Malouines," meaning Islands of Malo, the name French explorer Louis-Antoine de BOUGAINVILLE gave the islands in 1764 in honor of the French port of Saint-Malo

nodes.name: Location
nodes.data: Southern South America, islands in the South Atlantic Ocean, about 500 km east of southern Argentina

nodes.name: National coat of arms
nodes.data: the Falkland Islands adopted its coat of arms in 1948; the shield highlights the national symbol, the ram, which represents the country’s agricultural industry and stands on native tussock grass; English navigator John Davis’s sailing vessel, the Desire, is shown, referencing his sighting of the islands in 1592; below the shield is the national motto, “Desire the Right”

media.altText: The Falkland Islands adopted its coat of arms in 1948. The shield highlights the national symbol, the ram, which represents the countrys agricultural industry and stands on native tussock grass. English navigator John Daviss sailing vessel, the Desire, is shown, referencing his sighting of the islands in 1592. Below the shield is the Falklands motto, Desire the Right.
media.caption: The Falkland Islands adopted its coat of arms in 1948. The shield highlights the national symbol, the ram, which represents the countrys agricultural industry and stands on native tussock grass. English navigator John Daviss sailing vessel, the Desire, is shown, referencing his sighting of the islands in 1592. Below the shield is the Falklands motto, Desire the Right.
